titleStmt.title: Doha, Qatar National Library (مكتبة قطرالوطنية), HC.MS.2016.0015

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Qatar National Library, Heritage Library.

msContents.summary:
Single folio; Shelfmark: HC.MS.2016.0015; Qurʾānic Text: 038:076-039:021; Lines per page: 21; Dimensions: 332 x 222 mm; Script stye: ḥiǧāzī; Ductus: ḥiǧāzī with similarities to ḥiǧāzī I and ḥiǧāzī III; Estimated date of production: 650-720. Recent Provenance of this folio: Sotheby’s, London, 22 April 2015, lot 56.
Sister leaves: There are currently six folios known from this Qur’ān, the present leaf and five sister leaves, as follows (in order of Qur’ānic text):
(1) 006:141-006:158; Museum of Islamic Art, Doha, Ms.732.2011; (2) 007:169-007:194: Christie’s, London, 23 April 2015, lot 3; (3) 009:051-009:070: Sotheby’s, London, 23 October 2019, lot 104; (4) 012:030-012:051: Sotheby’s, London, 4 October 2011, lot 1; (5) 038:076-039:021: QNL, HC.MS.2016.0015; (6) 040:066-041:010: Christie’s, London, 7 April 2011, lot 10.

support.p: The number of lines per page on the six published folios from this Qur’an varies between 21 and 23. The present folio has 21 lines per page. The recto is the hair side of the parchment, the verso is flesh side. Verse separators consist of clusters of either four brown ink dots (2.1.2) or six brown dots (close to 2.1.5 type), formats that occur in many other manuscripts in ḥiǧāzī scripts (see Déroche 2014, figs. 1-3, 5, 7, 8, 9). There does not seem to be a pattern to which verses feature a cluster of four dots, and which a cluster of six dots. On the present folio verses 038:084 and 039:001, 039:003 (an additional verse separator), 039:006 and 039:010 have four-dot clusters, while all the others have six-dot clusters. However, it should be noted that several verse endings are not visible due to damage and loss of parchment. The end of the final verse of Sura Ṣād (038:088) is followed by a cluster of twelve dots made up of four columns of three dots. The division between the two suras has a gap one line high in which the title of sura 39 is written in red. The red ink of the title has mostly worn away and it is only possible to read the the words “...sabʿūna wa -ʾiṯnān...”(?)

summary.p: Ductus: ḥiǧāzī, with similarities to ḥiǧāzī I and ḥiǧāzī III Diacritics: There is partial use of letter-pointing, but no vowel signs. Letter-pointing is marked with brown ink dots of the same ink as the text and of the same shape as the nib-end of the calamus. The two dots indicating the tā’ are positioned vertically one above the other over the denticle. The three dots marking the ṯā’ are positioned above the denticle in a triangular cluster. The three dots indicating the šīn are placed one above each denticle in a horizontal row. Discussion of the script: The script has features found in scripts originally designated as ḥiǧāzī I, ḥiǧāzī II and ḥiǧāzī III (Déroche 1983, pp. 35-6). Overall the script is closest to that used on a fragment in the Oriental Institute Chicago A 7001, although on the present leaf and sister leaves the script is slightly more spaciously arranged and the letters slant slightly more to the right. Individual diagnostic letter forms in the script found on this leaf and on sister leaves from the same manuscript are as follows: The majority of examples of the independent ʾalif have a slight curve in the ascender and slope somewhat to the right. Some examples of the letter form curve to the right more emphatically at the base, giving those examples a short stub-like return. Other examples have a slightly straighter ascender with no lower return. In general the ascenders of the ʾalif and other letters with vertical elements are quite short. When ʾalif is followed immediately by lām, the two ascenders most often slant or curve away from each other, slightly diverging. The medial form ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ has an oblique stroke that drops below the line, as is typical of ḥiǧāzī scripts. Final ǧīm/ḥā’/ḫāʾ has a tail that is shaped in a fairly regular curve like a sickle, a form very similar to that found on A 7001 in the Oriental Institute (Chicago), and similar to some examples found on ms.or.fol.4313 in the Staatsbibliothek Berlin and Chester Beatty Library Ms.1615 II. Dāl/ḏāl varies slightly in its exact form, but all variations are found on other Qur’āns in ḥiǧāzī scripts as well as in scripts found on other media in the second half of the 7th century and the earliest years of the 8th century (see Fraser 2012, p. 129). The ascender of the ṭā’/ẓā’ slants slightly to the right and is similar to the form found on British Library manuscript Or. 2165 and BNF fragment Arabe 328e. Most examples of final ‘ayn and ġayn are similar to Hand B of the Codex Parisino-petropolitanus (Déroche 2014, fig. 2) and BNF Arabe 328e. Final fā’/qāf has a tail with a short vertical element immediately below the line which then curves into an open sickle-shaped hook, very similar to the forms found in ms.or.fol.4313 in the Staatsbibliothek Berlin and Chester Beatty Library Ms.1615 II. In the case of the final or independent kāf, the lower horizontal line extends considerably further to the left than the upper horizontal line, a useful diagnostic for ḥiǧāzī scripts (see Déroche 1999). The form found on the present script is similar to that in the British Library manuscript Or. 2165 and BNF fragment Arabe 328e and those in Hands C and E of the Codex Parisino-petropolitanus (Déroche 2014, figs. 3, 5), although the ascender here is slightly more vertical and the gap between the lower and upper horizontals is slightly more open. The lām-ʾalif has a fairly regular form with two diverging ascenders. The ascender that rises to the right is mostly straight, whereas the ascender that rises to the left is more often slightly curved. It resembles a slightly more rounded version of the lām-ʾalif found in Oriental Institute Chicago A 7001. Final mīm has two forms: one has a short horizontal tail, some of which curve upwards slightly; the other has a short pointed stub that points downwards. Both forms are found frequently in many examples of ḥiǧāzī script. Final nūn has an sickle-shaped form and is very similar to that found on A 7001 in the Oriental Institute, Chicago, and is also close to examples found on ms.or.fol.4313 in the Staatsbibliothek Berlin. The initial and medial form of hā’ has a distinctive upper diagonal tail that rises from the top and slants to the left. The form is very close to that found in the Chester Beatty Library Ms.1615 I and Chicago Oriental Institute A 7001, and not dissimilar to the form in British Library Ms. Or. 2165 and BNF fragment Arabe 328e, although the nib of the calamus here is slimmer. The final yā’ has a rounded hook shape very close to that found in Chicago Oriental Institute A 7001 and Berlin ms.or.fol.4313.
